name: Persian
description: Known for their long, luxurious coat and sweet personality. Persian cats are gentle, quiet, and adapt well to most environments.
history: The Persian cat is one of the oldest known breeds of cats. They were first seen in Europe in the 1600s and were originally called Angora cats. The breed was refined over time to develop the flat-faced appearance we see today.

name: Maine Coon
description: Large, gentle giants known for their intelligence and playful nature. They are one of the largest domestic cat breeds.
history: Originally working cats, Maine Coons are native to the state of Maine. They were popular mousers, ratters, and ship's cats. The breed nearly became extinct in the 1950s but was saved by dedicated breeders.

name: Siamese
description: Elegant and vocal cats with striking blue eyes and color points. They are known for being social and communicative.
history: One of the first distinctly recognized breeds of Asian cat. Siamese cats were described and illustrated in a collection of ancient manuscripts called the Tamra Maew (Cat Book Poems) thought to originate from the Ayutthaya Kingdom (1351 to 1767 AD).

name: British Shorthair
description: Robust cats with a distinctive round face and dense coat. They are calm, easy-going, and make excellent family pets.
history: The pedigreed version of the traditional British domestic cat. The breed was developed to have a distinctive stocky body, dense coat, and broad face. During WWI and WWII, the breed almost disappeared but was saved by crossing with Persians.

name: Ragdoll
description: Large, docile cats that go limp when picked up, hence their name. They are known for their calm temperament and beautiful blue eyes.
history: Developed in the 1960s by American breeder Ann Baker in Riverside, California. The breed was created by breeding Josephine, a white domestic longhair, with other cats she owned or found.

name: Bengal
description: Wild-looking cats with distinctive spotted or marbled coats. They are active, playful, and intelligent.
history: Created by crossing domestic cats with the Asian Leopard Cat. The breed was developed in the 1960s-70s by Jean Mill. Bengals retain the wild appearance of their leopard cat ancestors while having the temperament of a domestic cat.

name: Russian Blue
description: Elegant cats with a distinctive blue-gray coat and bright green eyes. They are shy but loyal to their families.
history: Believed to originate from the port city of Arkhangelsk in Russia. Sailors brought these cats to Great Britain and Northern Europe in the 1860s. They were almost extinct after WWII but were restored using Scandinavian and British bloodlines.

name: Sphynx
description: Hairless cats known for their extroverted behavior and warm, suede-like skin. They are very social and energetic.
history: The breed started in 1966 when a hairless kitten named Prune was born in Toronto, Canada. The breed was developed through selective breeding of hairless cats found in various locations.

name: Scottish Fold
description: Distinctive cats with folded ears that give them an owl-like appearance. They are sweet-natured and adapt well to other pets.
history: All Scottish Fold cats share a common ancestor: a white barn cat named Susie who was found at a farm near Coupar Angus in Perthshire, Scotland, in 1961. Susie's ears had an unusual fold in their middle.

name: Abyssinian
description: Active and playful cats with a distinctive ticked coat. They are intelligent, curious, and make excellent companions.
history: One of the oldest known cat breeds. Despite its name, genetic research suggests the breed originated near the coast of the Indian Ocean, in Southeast Asia. The first Abyssinian was exhibited in England in 1871.
